title: 110_hr4097
content:
There are no paragraphs provided in the prev_chunk, so I will summarize the curr_chunk as follows:

"SECTION 1. FINDINGS." Congress finds that Identification Friend or Foe equipment is crucial for the Armed Forces' operations in darkness and adverse conditions. Glo-patches and similar equipment must be destroyed to prevent restoration. Export of such equipment outside the US requires permission. Despite regulations, surplus combat uniforms with glo-tape patches were mistakenly sold in 2006. In 2006, surplus combat uniforms with glo-tape patches were sold despite regulations to remove and destroy the patches. In 2007, Iraqi insurgents disguised as US soldiers killed one soldier and abducted four others, showing the dangers of enemy disguise. Prohibition on sale or donation of Identification Friend or Foe equipment and accessories by the Department of Defense. The Secretary of Defense is prohibited from authorizing the sale, resale, or donation of Identification Friend or Foe equipment and accessories by the Department of Defense, with exceptions for sales to armed forces members for personal use and donations to museums for historical preservation. The Secretary of Defense is prohibited from selling or donating Identification Friend or Foe equipment and accessories, except for limited exceptions. The term refers to systems designed for military use and must be prominently marked as prohibited for sale on any media advertising surplus military equipment. The Department of Defense designed components for identifying armed forces members in poor lighting. A new item is added to the table of sections in the chapter regarding this equipment. SEC. 3. Prohibition on unauthorized possession of Identification Friend or Foe equipment and accessories. This section amends title 18, United States Code, to prohibit the manufacture, sale, or possession of any Identification Friend or Foe equipment or accessories without authorization. The equipment is designed for identifying armed forces members in poor lighting conditions. The amendments made by this section will be effective 30 days after the enactment of this Act.
